articles.title: Big Tech earnings on deck: What to expect from Meta & Apple
articles.content: Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) kicked off "Magnificent Seven" earnings, with the tech giant's hefty artificial intelligence (AI) capital expenditure (CapEx) catching investors' attention. Meta (META) and Apple (AAPL) are among the other Big Tech names set to report earnings next. CFRA Research chief investment strategist Sam Stovall and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Ines Ferré outline what they're watching for during Meta and Apple earnings. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid here.

articles.title: Apple Earnings Are Next Week. Why This Analyst Says Be Cautious.
articles.content: Apple’s  lagging progress with artificial intelligence should give investors pause heading into earnings next week, Needham says.  Wall Street will be closely monitoring  Apple’s  earnings report on July 31 amid a challenging time for the stock.  While the  has risen 8.5% this year,  Apple  shares have dropped 14%.

articles.title: Apple Faces Existential Threat If It Fails To Act On GenAI
articles.content: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) is facing mounting pressure from investors as concerns intensify over its lagging generative AI (GenAI) strategy, a key driver of growth across the tech sector. With the company’s shares down 14% year-to-date, contrasting sharply with the S&P 500’s 8% gain, the market is signaling a clear demand for a definitive plan to catch up with rivals like Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google and Meta Platforms (NASDAQ:META), which have aggressively integrated AI into their offerings. articles.title: Berkshire Stock Is Losing Its Buffett Premium. Now Is the Time to Buy.
articles.content: Berkshire Hathaway stock has been in a funk since the company’s May 3 annual meeting, when CEO Warren Buffett said he would step down as CEO at the end of the year.  Shares of  Berkshire  have declined over 10% since the meeting, trailing the  by more than 20 percentage points after outperforming at the start of the year.  Several factors are behind the flagging performance: an erosion in the “Buffett premium”; concern that the property-and-casualty insurance cycle has peaked; scant new investment activity by the company; no stock buybacks in more than a year, and a recent shift away from defensive stocks like Berkshire.

articles.title: Lyft's autonomous plans, Apple, McDonald's: Trending Tickers
articles.content: Lyft (LYFT) teams up with Benteler Group to make autonomous shuttles with a planned launch in 2026. JPMorgan analysts are bullish on Apple (AAPL) ahead of the iPhone maker's earnings report next week, saying the near-term positioning is better than feared. McDonald's (MCD) is reportedly planning to launch premium beverage options, according to the Wall Street Journal.
